repnme.cdata!: Micro-credits support a growing rural economy

abstracts.cdata!:
A World Bank project launched
            experimentally in 1992 offered a welcome alternative to dire
            poverty or hard-knock immigration. The idea was to: offer
            small loans to trustworthy villagers and wait for their
            investments to bear fruit. This micro-credit scheme,
            supported with additional World Bank funds in 1999, has
            grown into a successful network of rural micro-credit
            associations serving over 10,000 members. Micro-credit
            institutions, based on individual trust and solidarity
            between villagers, fill an important gap in the financial
            fabric of the country. Together with remittances sent by
            workers overseas, small loans helped Albanians emerge from
            the deep crisis of the 1990s. Now the credits support the
            growth of a promising rural economy. Most of the loans still
            finance agricultural and livestock investments but the share
            of trade, tourism, and crafts is increasing.

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Microcredit Project
            for Albania was satisfactory, the sustainability was highly
            likely, the institutional development impact was high, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: The legal and regulatory
            environment should be designed early on in the process, to
            make sure that this environment is conducive to the growth
            of the industry and that the supervisor works closely with
            its supervisees. A major financing gap should not be
            initiated if the gap is critical for the project to reach
            its development objectives. Stand alone microfinance or
            rural finance projects are more likely to be best practice
            than small microfinance components within larger non-finance
            projects. Savings cannot be expected to replace credit lines
            in the short-term, therefore, reflows may have to be used
            for a fairly extended period of time. A budget support
            funding mechanism directly to the microfinance institutions,
            instead of a cumbersome micromanagement of the
            project's expenses and procedures, has proven to
            increase the level of responsibility and ownership in the
            micro-finance institutions. Building microfinance
            institutions from a start-up position takes a long time.

5084574.majtheme: Rule of law,Rural development,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Micro-credit Project for Albania
            aims to address private sector development and poverty
            alleviation by increasing the availability of financial
            services to rural farmers and entrepreneurs and urban
            micro-entrepreneurs and the self-employed. The project has
            four components. The first component helps establish and
            extend a private, sustainable savings and credit association
            (SCA) network in rural areas-using as a basis the current
            system of village credit funds-and the progressive
            development of an SCA Union. The second component expands
            urban micro-credit and the development of a private,
            sustainable micro-credit institution, established from the
            existing Urban Credit Department of the Albanian Development
            Fund (ADF). The third component provides technical
            assistance and training to develop an appropriate legal,
            regulatory, and supervision framework for rural SCAs and
            their Union, and micro-credit nongovernmental organizations.
            The fourth component finances project management.
